verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses, “How long will these people treat me with contempt? Will they never believe me, even after all the miraculous signs I have done among them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will disown them and destroy them with a plague. Then I will make you into a nation greater and mightier than they are!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses objected. “What will the Egyptians think when they hear about it?” he asked the Lord. “They know full well the power you displayed in rescuing your people from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you destroy them, the Egyptians will send a report to the inhabitants of this land, who have already heard that you live among your people. They know, Lord, that you have appeared to your people face to face and that your pillar of cloud hovers over them. They know that you go before them in the pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you slaughter all these people with a single blow, the nations that have heard of your fame will say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The Lord was not able to bring them into the land he swore to give them, so he killed them in the wilderness.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Please, Lord, prove that your power is as great as you have claimed. For you said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The Lord is slow to anger and filled with unfailing love, forgiving every kind of sin and rebellion. But he does not excuse the guilty. He lays the sins of the parents upon their children; the entire family is affected—even children in the third and fourth generations.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In keeping with your magnificent, unfailing love, please pardon the sins of this people, just as you have forgiven them ever since they left Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, “I will pardon them as you have requested.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as surely as I live, and as surely as the earth is filled with the Lord’s glory,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not one of these people will ever enter that land. They have all seen my glorious presence and the miraculous signs I performed both in Egypt and in the wilderness, but again and again they have tested me by refusing to listen to my voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will never even see the land I swore to give their ancestors. None of those who have treated me with contempt will ever see it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my servant Caleb has a different attitude than the others have. He has remained loyal to me, so I will bring him into the land he explored. His descendants will possess their full share of that land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now turn around, and don’t go on toward the land where the Amalekites and Canaanites live. Tomorrow you must set out for the wilderness in the direction of the Red Sea.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How long must I put up with this wicked community and its complaints about me? Yes, I have heard the complaints the Israelites are making against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now tell them this: ‘As surely as I live, declares the Lord, I will do to you the very things I heard you say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will all drop dead in this wilderness! Because you complained against me, every one of you who is twenty years old or older and was included in the registration will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will not enter and occupy the land I swore to give you. The only exceptions will be Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘You said your children would be carried off as plunder. Well, I will bring them safely into the land, and they will enjoy what you have despised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you, you will drop dead in this wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And your children will be like shepherds, wandering in the wilderness for forty years. In this way, they will pay for your faithlessness, until the last of you lies dead in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘Because your men explored the land for forty days, you must wander in the wilderness for forty years—a year for each day, suffering the consequences of your sins. Then you will discover what it is like to have me for an enemy.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Lord, have spoken! I will certainly do these things to every member of the community who has conspired against me. They will be destroyed here in this wilderness, and here they will die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ten men Moses had sent to explore the land—the ones who incited rebellion against the Lord with their bad report—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: were struck dead with a plague before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of the twelve who had explored the land, only Joshua and Caleb remained alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses reported the Lord’s words to all the Israelites, the people were filled with grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they got up early the next morning and went to the top of the range of hills. “Let’s go,” they said. “We realize that we have sinned, but now we are ready to enter the land the Lord has promised us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, “Why are you now disobeying the Lord’s orders to return to the wilderness? It won’t work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not go up into the land now. You will only be crushed by your enemies because the Lord is not with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you face the Amalekites and Canaanites in battle, you will be slaughtered. The Lord will abandon you because you have abandoned the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people defiantly pushed ahead toward the hill country, even though neither Moses nor the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant left the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in those hills came down and attacked them and chased them back as far as Hormah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Give the following instructions to the people of Israel.
“When you finally settle in the land I am giving you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you will offer special gifts as a pleasing aroma to the Lord. These gifts may take the form of a burnt offering, a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, a voluntary offering, or an offering at any of your annual festivals, and they may be taken from your herds of cattle or your flocks of sheep and goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you present these offerings, you must also give the Lord a grain offering of two quarts of choice flour mixed with one quart of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For each lamb offered as a burnt offering or a special sacrifice, you must also present one quart of wine as a liquid offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If the sacrifice is a ram, give a grain offering of four quarts of choice flour mixed with a third of a gallon of olive oil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and give a third of a gallon of wine as a liquid offering. This will be a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you present a young bull as a burnt offering or as a sacrifice to fulfill a vow or as a peace offering to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: you must also give a grain offering of six quarts of choice flour mixed with two quarts of olive oil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and give two quarts of wine as a liquid offering. This will be a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Each sacrifice of a bull, ram, lamb, or young goat should be prepared in this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Follow these instructions with each offering you present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of you native-born Israelites must follow these instructions when you offer a special gift as a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if any foreigners visit you or live among you and want to present a special gift as a pleasing aroma to the Lord, they must follow these same procedures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Native-born Israelites and foreigners are equal before the Lord and are subject to the same decrees. This is a permanent law for you, to be observed from generation to generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The same instructions and regulations will apply both to you and to the foreigners living among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Give the following instructions to the people of Israel.
“When you arrive in the land where I am taking you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and you eat the crops that grow there, you must set some aside as a sacred offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Present a cake from the first of the flour you grind, and set it aside as a sacred offering, as you do with the first grain from the threshing floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout the generations to come, you are to present a sacred offering to the Lord each year from the first of your ground flour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But suppose you unintentionally fail to carry out all these commands that the Lord has given you through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And suppose your descendants in the future fail to do everything the Lord has commanded through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the mistake was made unintentionally, and the community was unaware of it, the whole community must present a young bull for a burnt offering as a pleasing aroma to the Lord. It must be offered along with its prescribed grain offering and liquid offering and with one male goat for a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With it the priest will purify the whole community of Israel, making them right with the Lord, and they will be forgiven. For it was an unintentional sin, and they have corrected it with their offerings to the Lord—the special gift and the sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole community of Israel will be forgiven, including the foreigners living among you, for all the people were involved in the sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If one individual commits an unintentional sin, the guilty person must bring a one-year-old female goat for a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest will sacrifice it to purify the guilty person before the Lord, and that person will be forgiven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These same instructions apply both to native-born Israelites and to the foreigners living among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But those who brazenly violate the Lord’s will, whether native-born Israelites or foreigners, have blasphemed the Lord, and they must be cut off from the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since they have treated the Lord’s word with contempt and deliberately disobeyed his command, they must be completely cut off and suffer the punishment for their guilt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day while the people of Israel were in the wilderness, they discovered a man gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who found him doing this took him before Moses, Aaron, and the rest of the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They held him in custody because they did not know what to do with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man must be put to death! The whole community must stone him outside the camp.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the whole community took the man outside the camp and stoned him to death, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel: Throughout the generations to come you must make tassels for the hems of your clothing and attach them with a blue cord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you see the tassels, you will remember and obey all the commands of the Lord instead of following your own desires and defiling yourselves, as you are prone to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tassels will help you remember that you must obey all my commands and be holy to your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the Lord your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt that I might be your God. I am the Lord your God!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day Korah son of Izhar, a descendant of Kohath son of Levi, conspired with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On son of Peleth, from the tribe of Reuben.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They incited a rebellion against Moses, along with 250 other leaders of the community, all prominent members of the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They united against Moses and Aaron and said, “You have gone too far! The whole community of Israel has been set apart by the Lord, and he is with all of us. What right do you have to act as though you are greater than the rest of the Lord’s people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses heard what they were saying, he fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to Korah and his followers, “Tomorrow morning the Lord will show us who belongs to him and who is holy. The Lord will allow only those whom he selects to enter his own presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Korah, you and all your followers must prepare your incense burners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Light fires in them tomorrow, and burn incense before the Lord. Then we will see whom the Lord chooses as his holy one. You Levites are the ones who have gone too far!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses spoke again to Korah: “Now listen, you Levites!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Does it seem insignificant to you that the God of Israel has chosen you from among all the community of Israel to be near him so you can serve in the Lord’s Tabernacle and stand before the people to minister to them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Korah, he has already given this special ministry to you and your fellow Levites. Are you now demanding the priesthood as well?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord is the one you and your followers are really revolting against! For who is Aaron that you are complaining about him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, but they replied, “We refuse to come before you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t it enough that you brought us out of Egypt, a land flowing with milk and honey, to kill us here in this wilderness, and that you now treat us like your subjects?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What’s more, you haven’t brought us into another land flowing with milk and honey. You haven’t given us a new homeland with fields and vineyards. Are you trying to fool these men? We will not come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses became very angry and said to the Lord, “Do not accept their grain offerings! I have not taken so much as a donkey from them, and I have never hurt a single one of them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said to Korah, “You and all your followers must come here tomorrow and present yourselves before the Lord. Aaron will also be here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and each of your 250 followers must prepare an incense burner and put incense on it, so you can all present them before the Lord. Aaron will also bring his incense burner.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So each of these men prepared an incense burner, lit the fire, and placed incense on it. Then they all stood at the entrance of the Tabernacle with Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Korah had stirred up the entire community against Moses and Aaron, and they all gathered at the Tabernacle entrance. Then the glorious presence of the Lord appeared to the whole community,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get away from all these people so that I may instantly destroy them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses and Aaron fell face down on the ground. “O God,” they pleaded, “you are the God who gives breath to all creatures. Must you be angry with all the people when only one man sins?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then tell all the people to get away from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses got up and rushed over to the tents of Dathan and Abiram, followed by the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Quick!” he told the people. “Get away from the tents of these wicked men, and don’t touch anything that belongs to them. If you do, you will be destroyed for their sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people stood back from the tents of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram. Then Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrances of their tents, together with their wives and children and little ones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said, “This is how you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these things that I have done—for I have not done them on my own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If these men die a natural death, or if nothing unusual happens, then the Lord has not sent me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the Lord does something entirely new and the ground opens its mouth and swallows them and all their belongings, and they go down alive into the grave, then you will know that these men have shown contempt for the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had hardly finished speaking the words when the ground suddenly split open beneath them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed the men, along with their households and all their followers who were standing with them, and everything they owned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went down alive into the grave, along with all their belongings. The earth closed over them, and they all vanished from among the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people around them fled when they heard their screams. “The earth will swallow us, too!” they cried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then fire blazed forth from the Lord and burned up the 250 men who were offering incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell Eleazar son of Aaron the priest to pull all the incense burners from the fire, for they are holy. Also tell him to scatter the burning coals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the incense burners of these men who have sinned at the cost of their lives, and hammer the metal into a thin sheet to overlay the altar. Since these burners were used in the Lord’s presence, they have become holy. Let them serve as a warning to the people of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Eleazar the priest collected the 250 bronze incense burners that had been used by the men who died in the fire, and the bronze was hammered into a thin sheet to overlay the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This would warn the Israelites that no unauthorized person—no one who was not a descendant of Aaron—should ever enter the Lord’s presence to burn incense. If anyone did, the same thing would happen to him as happened to Korah and his followers. So the Lord’s instructions to Moses were carried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the very next morning the whole community of Israel began muttering again against Moses and Aaron, saying, “You have killed the Lord’s people!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the community gathered to protest against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the Tabernacle and saw that the cloud had covered it, and the glorious presence of the Lord appeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron came and stood in front of the Tabernacle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get away from all these people so that I can instantly destroy them!” But Moses and Aaron fell face down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Moses said to Aaron, “Quick, take an incense burner and place burning coals on it from the altar. Lay incense on it, and carry it out among the people to purify them and make them right with the Lord. The Lord’s anger is blazing against them—the plague has already begun.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron did as Moses told him and ran out among the people. The plague had already begun to strike down the people, but Aaron burned the incense and purified the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stood between the dead and the living, and the plague stopped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But 14,700 people died in that plague, in addition to those who had died in the affair involving Korah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then because the plague had stopped, Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the people of Israel to bring you twelve wooden staffs, one from each leader of Israel’s ancestral tribes, and inscribe each leader’s name on his staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Inscribe Aaron’s name on the staff of the tribe of Levi, for there must be one staff for the leader of each ancestral tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Place these staffs in the Tabernacle in front of the Ark containing the tablets of the Covenant, where I meet with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Buds will sprout on the staff belonging to the man I choose. Then I will finally put an end to the people’s murmuring and complaining against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses gave the instructions to the people of Israel, and each of the twelve tribal leaders, including Aaron, brought Moses a staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses placed the staffs in the Lord’s presence in the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he went into the Tabernacle of the Covenant the next day, he found that Aaron’s staff, representing the tribe of Levi, had sprouted, budded, blossomed, and produced ripe almonds!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses brought all the staffs out from the Lord’s presence, he showed them to the people. Each man claimed his own staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Moses: “Place Aaron’s staff permanently before the Ark of the Covenant to serve as a warning to rebels. This should put an end to their complaints against me and prevent any further deaths.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses did as the Lord commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel said to Moses, “Look, we are doomed! We are dead! We are ruined!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who even comes close to the Tabernacle of the Lord dies. Are we all doomed to die?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Aaron: “You, your sons, and your relatives from the tribe of Levi will be held responsible for any offenses related to the sanctuary. But you and your sons alone will be held responsible for violations connected with the priesthood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Bring your relatives of the tribe of Levi—your ancestral tribe—to assist you and your sons as you perform the sacred duties in front of the Tabernacle of the Covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as the Levites go about all their assigned duties at the Tabernacle, they must be careful not to go near any of the sacred objects or the altar. If they do, both you and they will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites must join you in fulfilling their responsibilities for the care and maintenance of the Tabernacle, but no unauthorized person may assist you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You yourselves must perform the sacred duties inside the sanctuary and at the altar. If you follow these instructions, the Lord’s anger will never again blaze against the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself have chosen your fellow Levites from among the Israelites to be your special assistants. They are a gift to you, dedicated to the Lord for service in the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you and your sons, the priests, must personally handle all the priestly rituals associated with the altar and with everything behind the inner curtain. I am giving you the priesthood as your special privilege of service. Any unauthorized person who comes too near the sanctuary will be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave these further instructions to Aaron: “I myself have put you in charge of all the holy offerings that are brought to me by the people of Israel. I have given all these consecrated offerings to you and your sons as your permanent share.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are allotted the portion of the most holy offerings that is not burned on the fire. This portion of all the most holy offerings—including the grain offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings—will be most holy, and it belongs to you and your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must eat it as a most holy offering. All the males may eat of it, and you must treat it as most holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All the sacred offerings and special offerings presented to me when the Israelites lift them up before the altar also belong to you. I have given them to you and to your sons and daughters as your permanent share. Any member of your family who is ceremonially clean may eat of these offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I also give you the harvest gifts brought by the people as offerings to the Lord—the best of the olive oil, new wine, and grain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the first crops of their land that the people present to the Lord belong to you. Any member of your family who is ceremonially clean may eat this food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Everything in Israel that is specially set apart for the Lord also belongs to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The firstborn of every mother, whether human or animal, that is offered to the Lord will be yours. But you must always redeem your firstborn sons and the firstborn of ceremonially unclean animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Redeem them when they are one month old. The redemption price is five pieces of silver (as measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel, which equals twenty gerahs).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, you may not redeem the firstborn of cattle, sheep, or goats. They are holy and have been set apart for the Lord. Sprinkle their blood on the altar, and burn their fat as a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The meat of these animals will be yours, just like the breast and right thigh that are presented by lifting them up as a special offering before the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, I am giving you all these holy offerings that the people of Israel bring to the Lord. They are for you and your sons and daughters, to be eaten as your permanent share. This is an eternal and unbreakable covenant between the Lord and you, and it also applies to your descendants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said to Aaron, “You priests will receive no allotment of land or share of property among the people of Israel. I am your share and your allotment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the tribe of Levi, your relatives, I will compensate them for their service in the Tabernacle. Instead of an allotment of land, I will give them the tithes from the entire land of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From now on, no Israelites except priests or Levites may approach the Tabernacle. If they come too near, they will be judged guilty and will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only the Levites may serve at the Tabernacle, and they will be held responsible for any offenses against it. This is a permanent law for you, to be observed from generation to generation. The Levites will receive no allotment of land among the Israelites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I have given them the Israelites’ tithes, which have been presented as sacred offerings to the Lord. This will be the Levites’ share. That is why I said they would receive no allotment of land among the Israelites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Give these instructions to the Levites: When you receive from the people of Israel the tithes I have assigned as your allotment, give a tenth of the tithes you receive—a tithe of the tithe—to the Lord as a sacred offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will consider this offering to be your harvest offering, as though it were the first grain from your own threshing floor or wine from your own winepress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must present one-tenth of the tithe received from the Israelites as a sacred offering to the Lord. This is the Lord’s sacred portion, and you must present it to Aaron the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be sure to give to the Lord the best portions of the gifts given to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Also, give these instructions to the Levites: When you present the best part as your offering, it will be considered as though it came from your own threshing floor or winepress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You Levites and your families may eat this food anywhere you wish, for it is your compensation for serving in the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will not be considered guilty for accepting the Lord’s tithes if you give the best portion to the priests. But be careful not to treat the holy gifts of the people of Israel as though they were common. If you do, you will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here is another legal requirement commanded by the Lord: Tell the people of Israel to bring you a red heifer, a perfect animal that has no defects and has never been yoked to a plow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give it to Eleazar the priest, and it will be taken outside the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eleazar will take some of its blood on his finger and sprinkle it seven times toward the front of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Eleazar watches, the heifer must be burned—its hide, meat, blood, and dung.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eleazar the priest must then take a stick of cedar, a hyssop branch, and some scarlet yarn and throw them into the fire where the heifer is burning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the priest must wash his clothes and bathe himself in water. Afterward he may return to the camp, though he will remain ceremonially unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who burns the animal must also wash his clothes and bathe himself in water, and he, too, will remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then someone who is ceremonially clean will gather up the ashes of the heifer and deposit them in a purified place outside the camp. They will be kept there for the community of Israel to use in the water for the purification ceremony. This ceremony is performed for the removal of sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man who gathers up the ashes of the heifer must also wash his clothes, and he will remain ceremonially unclean until evening. This is a permanent law for the people of Israel and any foreigners who live among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All those who touch a dead human body will be ceremonially unclean for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They must purify themselves on the third and seventh days with the water of purification; then they will be purified. But if they do not do this on the third and seventh days, they will continue to be unclean even after the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All those who touch a dead body and do not purify themselves in the proper way defile the Lord’s Tabernacle, and they will be cut off from the community of Israel. Since the water of purification was not sprinkled on them, their defilement continues.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is the ritual law that applies when someone dies inside a tent: All those who enter that tent and those who were inside when the death occurred will be ceremonially unclean for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any open container in the tent that was not covered with a lid is also defiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if someone in an open field touches the corpse of someone who was killed with a sword or who died a natural death, or if someone touches a human bone or a grave, that person will be defiled for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “To remove the defilement, put some of the ashes from the burnt purification offering in a jar, and pour fresh water over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then someone who is ceremonially clean must take a hyssop branch and dip it into the water. That person must sprinkle the water on the tent, on all the furnishings in the tent, and on the people who were in the tent; also on the person who touched a human bone, or touched someone who was killed or who died naturally, or touched a grave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third and seventh days the person who is ceremonially clean must sprinkle the water on those who are defiled. Then on the seventh day the people being cleansed must wash their clothes and bathe themselves, and that evening they will be cleansed of their defilement.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But those who become defiled and do not purify themselves will be cut off from the community, for they have defiled the sanctuary of the Lord. Since the water of purification has not been sprinkled on them, they remain defiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is a permanent law for the people. Those who sprinkle the water of purification must afterward wash their clothes, and anyone who then touches the water used for purification will remain defiled until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anything and anyone that a defiled person touches will be ceremonially unclean until evening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month of the year, the whole community of Israel arrived in the wilderness of Zin and camped at Kadesh. While they were there, Miriam died and was buried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no water for the people to drink at that place, so they rebelled against Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people blamed Moses and said, “If only we had died in the Lord’s presence with our brothers!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why have you brought the congregation of the Lord’s people into this wilderness to die, along with all our livestock?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you make us leave Egypt and bring us here to this terrible place? This land has no grain, no figs, no grapes, no pomegranates, and no water to drink!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron turned away from the people and went to the entrance of the Tabernacle, where they fell face down on the ground. Then the glorious presence of the Lord appeared to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You and Aaron must take the staff and assemble the entire community. As the people watch, speak to the rock over there, and it will pour out its water. You will provide enough water from the rock to satisfy the whole community and their livestock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses did as he was told. He took the staff from the place where it was kept before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he and Aaron summoned the people to come and gather at the rock. “Listen, you rebels!” he shouted. “Must we bring you water from this rock?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses raised his hand and struck the rock twice with the staff, and water gushed out. So the entire community and their livestock drank their fill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust me enough to demonstrate my holiness to the people of Israel, you will not lead them into the land I am giving them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This place was known as the waters of Meribah (which means “arguing”) because there the people of Israel argued with the Lord, and there he demonstrated his holiness among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While Moses was at Kadesh, he sent ambassadors to the king of Edom with this message:
“This is what your relatives, the people of Israel, say: You know all the hardships we have been through.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our ancestors went down to Egypt, and we lived there a long time, and we and our ancestors were brutally mistreated by the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when we cried out to the Lord, he heard us and sent an angel who brought us out of Egypt. Now we are camped at Kadesh, a town on the border of your land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please let us travel through your land. We will be careful not to go through your fields and vineyards. We won’t even drink water from your wells. We will stay on the king’s road and never leave it until we have passed through your territory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Edom said, “Stay out of my land, or I will meet you with an army!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites answered, “We will stay on the main road. If our livestock drink your water, we will pay for it. Just let us pass through your country. That’s all we ask.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Edom replied, “Stay out! You may not pass through our land.” With that he mobilized his army and marched out against them with an imposing force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because Edom refused to allow Israel to pass through their country, Israel was forced to turn around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole community of Israel left Kadesh and arrived at Mount Hor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, on the border of the land of Edom, the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The time has come for Aaron to join his ancestors in death. He will not enter the land I am giving the people of Israel, because the two of you rebelled against my instructions concerning the water at Meribah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now take Aaron and his son Eleazar up Mount Hor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There you will remove Aaron’s priestly garments and put them on Eleazar, his son. Aaron will die there and join his ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses did as the Lord commanded. The three of them went up Mount Hor together as the whole community watched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the summit, Moses removed the priestly garments from Aaron and put them on Eleazar, Aaron’s son. Then Aaron died there on top of the mountain, and Moses and Eleazar went back down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people realized that Aaron had died, all Israel mourned for him thirty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that the Israelites were approaching on the road through Atharim. So he attacked the Israelites and took some of them as prisoners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel made this vow to the Lord: “If you will hand these people over to us, we will completely destroy all their towns.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord heard the Israelites’ request and gave them victory over the Canaanites. The Israelites completely destroyed them and their towns, and the place has been called Hormah ever since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel set out from Mount Hor, taking the road to the Red Sea to go around the land of Edom. But the people grew impatient with the long journey,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they began to speak against God and Moses. “Why have you brought us out of Egypt to die here in the wilderness?” they complained. “There is nothing to eat here and nothing to drink. And we hate this horrible manna!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord sent poisonous snakes among the people, and many were bitten and died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people came to Moses and cried out, “We have sinned by speaking against the Lord and against you. Pray that the Lord will take away the snakes.” So Moses prayed for the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told him, “Make a replica of a poisonous snake and attach it to a pole. All who are bitten will live if they simply look at it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses made a snake out of bronze and attached it to a pole. Then anyone who was bitten by a snake could look at the bronze snake and be healed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites traveled next to Oboth and camped there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they went on to Iye-abarim, in the wilderness on the eastern border of Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there they traveled to the valley of Zered Brook and set up camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they moved out and camped on the far side of the Arnon River, in the wilderness adjacent to the territory of the Amorites. The Arnon is the boundary line between the Moabites and the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason The Book of the Wars of the Lord speaks of “the town of Waheb in the area of Suphah, and the ravines of the Arnon River,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the ravines that extend as far as the settlement of Ar on the border of Moab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there the Israelites traveled to Beer, which is the well where the Lord said to Moses, “Assemble the people, and I will give them water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the Israelites sang this song:
“Spring up, O well!
    Yes, sing its praises!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sing of this well,
    which princes dug,
which great leaders hollowed out
    with their scepters and staffs.”
Then the Israelites left the wilderness and proceeded on through Mattanah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahaliel, and Bamoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that they went to the valley in Moab where Pisgah Peak overlooks the wasteland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites sent ambassadors to King Sihon of the Amorites with this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let us travel through your land. We will be careful not to go through your fields and vineyards. We won’t even drink water from your wells. We will stay on the king’s road until we have passed through your territory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Sihon refused to let them cross his territory. Instead, he mobilized his entire army and attacked Israel in the wilderness, engaging them in battle at Jahaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelites slaughtered them with their swords and occupied their land from the Arnon River to the Jabbok River. They went only as far as the Ammonite border because the boundary of the Ammonites was fortified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel captured all the towns of the Amorites and settled in them, including the city of Heshbon and its surrounding villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heshbon had been the capital of King Sihon of the Amorites. He had defeated a former Moabite king and seized all his land as far as the Arnon River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore, the ancient poets wrote this about him:
“Come to Heshbon and let it be rebuilt!
    Let the city of Sihon be restored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fire flamed forth from Heshbon,
    a blaze from the city of Sihon.
It burned the city of Ar in Moab;
    it destroyed the rulers of the Arnon heights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What sorrow awaits you, O people of Moab!
    You are finished, O worshipers of Chemosh!
Chemosh has left his sons as refugees,
    his daughters as captives of Sihon, the Amorite king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have utterly destroyed them,
    from Heshbon to Dibon.
We have completely wiped them out
    as far away as Nophah and Medeba.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people of Israel occupied the territory of the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses sent men to explore the Jazer area, they captured all the towns in the region and drove out the Amorites who lived there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they turned and marched up the road to Bashan, but King Og of Bashan and all his people attacked them at Edrei.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Do not be afraid of him, for I have handed him over to you, along with all his people and his land. Do the same to him as you did to King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Israel killed King Og, his sons, and all his subjects; not a single survivor remained. Then Israel occupied their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel traveled to the plains of Moab and camped east of the Jordan River, across from Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak son of Zippor, the Moabite king, had seen everything the Israelites did to the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the people of Moab saw how many Israelites there were, they were terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Moab said to the elders of Midian, “This mob will devour everything in sight, like an ox devours grass in the field!”
So Balak, king of Moab,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
sent messengers to call Balaam son of Beor, who was living in his native land of Pethor near the Euphrates River. His message said:
“Look, a vast horde of people has arrived from Egypt. They cover the face of the earth and are threatening me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please come and curse these people for me because they are too powerful for me. Then perhaps I will be able to conquer them and drive them from the land. I know that blessings fall on any people you bless, and curses fall on people you curse.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak’s messengers, who were elders of Moab and Midian, set out with money to pay Balaam to place a curse upon Israel. They went to Balaam and delivered Balak’s message to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Stay here overnight,” Balaam said. “In the morning I will tell you whatever the Lord directs me to say.” So the officials from Moab stayed there with Balaam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night God came to Balaam and asked him, “Who are these men visiting you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam said to God, “Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, has sent me this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Look, a vast horde of people has arrived from Egypt, and they cover the face of the earth. Come and curse these people for me. Then perhaps I will be able to stand up to them and drive them from the land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God told Balaam, “Do not go with them. You are not to curse these people, for they have been blessed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning Balaam got up and told Balak’s officials, “Go on home! The Lord will not let me go with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Moabite officials returned to King Balak and reported, “Balaam refused to come with us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balak tried again. This time he sent a larger number of even more distinguished officials than those he had sent the first time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They went to Balaam and delivered this message to him:
“This is what Balak son of Zippor says: Please don’t let anything stop you from coming to help me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will pay you very well and do whatever you tell me. Just come and curse these people for me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Balaam responded to Balak’s messengers, “Even if Balak were to give me his palace filled with silver and gold, I would be powerless to do anything against the will of the Lord my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But stay here one more night, and I will see if the Lord has anything else to say to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night God came to Balaam and told him, “Since these men have come for you, get up and go with them. But do only what I tell you to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the next morning Balaam got up, saddled his donkey, and started off with the Moabite officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God was angry that Balaam was going, so he sent the angel of the Lord to stand in the road to block his way. As Balaam and two servants were riding along,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam’s donkey saw the angel of the Lord standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand. The donkey bolted off the road into a field, but Balaam beat it and turned it back onto the road.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord stood at a place where the road narrowed between two vineyard walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, it tried to squeeze by and crushed Balaam’s foot against the wall. So Balaam beat the donkey again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord moved farther down the road and stood in a place too narrow for the donkey to get by at all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This time when the donkey saw the angel, it lay down under Balaam. In a fit of rage Balaam beat the animal again with his staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave the donkey the ability to speak. “What have I done to you that deserves your beating me three times?” it asked Balaam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You have made me look like a fool!” Balaam shouted. “If I had a sword with me, I would kill you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“But I am the same donkey you have ridden all your life,” the donkey answered. “Have I ever done anything like this before?”
“No,” Balaam admitted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing in the roadway with a drawn sword in his hand. Balaam bowed his head and fell face down on the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why did you beat your donkey those three times?” the angel of the Lord demanded. “Look, I have come to block your way because you are stubbornly resisting me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times the donkey saw me and shied away; otherwise, I would certainly have killed you by now and spared the donkey.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam confessed to the angel of the Lord, “I have sinned. I didn’t realize you were standing in the road to block my way. I will return home if you are against my going.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the angel of the Lord told Balaam, “Go with these men, but say only what I tell you to say.” So Balaam went on with Balak’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Balak heard that Balaam was on the way, he went out to meet him at a Moabite town on the Arnon River at the farthest border of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Didn’t I send you an urgent invitation? Why didn’t you come right away?” Balak asked Balaam. “Didn’t you believe me when I said I would reward you richly?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam replied, “Look, now I have come, but I have no power to say whatever I want. I will speak only the message that God puts in my mouth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam accompanied Balak to Kiriath-huzoth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where the king sacrificed cattle and sheep. He sent portions of the meat to Balaam and the officials who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning Balak took Balaam up to Bamoth-baal. From there he could see some of the people of Israel spread out below him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam said to King Balak, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven young bulls and seven rams for me to sacrifice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak followed his instructions, and the two of them sacrificed a young bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Stand here by your burnt offerings, and I will go to see if the Lord will respond to me. Then I will tell you whatever he reveals to me.” So Balaam went alone to the top of a bare hill,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and God met him there. Balaam said to him, “I have prepared seven altars and have sacrificed a young bull and a ram on each altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave Balaam a message for King Balak. Then he said, “Go back to Balak and give him my message.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balaam returned and found the king standing beside his burnt offerings with all the officials of Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This was the message Balaam delivered:
“Balak summoned me to come from Aram;
    the king of Moab brought me from the eastern hills.
‘Come,’ he said, ‘curse Jacob for me!
    Come and announce Israel’s doom.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But how can I curse those
    whom God has not cursed?
How can I condemn those
    whom the Lord has not condemned?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I see them from the cliff tops;
    I watch them from the hills.
I see a people who live by themselves,
    set apart from other nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can count Jacob’s descendants, as numerous as dust?
    Who can count even a fourth of Israel’s people?
Let me die like the righteous;
    let my life end like theirs.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Balak demanded of Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies. Instead, you have blessed them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Balaam replied, “I will speak only the message that the Lord puts in my mouth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Balak told him, “Come with me to another place. There you will see another part of the nation of Israel, but not all of them. Curse at least that many!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak took Balaam to the plateau of Zophim on Pisgah Peak. He built seven altars there and offered a young bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam said to the king, “Stand here by your burnt offerings while I go over there to meet the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord met Balaam and gave him a message. Then he said, “Go back to Balak and give him my message.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balaam returned and found the king standing beside his burnt offerings with all the officials of Moab. “What did the Lord say?” Balak asked eagerly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This was the message Balaam delivered:
“Rise up, Balak, and listen!
    Hear me, son of Zippor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is not a man, so he does not lie.
    He is not human, so he does not change his mind.
Has he ever spoken and failed to act?
    Has he ever promised and not carried it through?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, I received a command to bless;
    God has blessed, and I cannot reverse it!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
God brought them out of Egypt;
    for them he is as strong as a wild ox.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No curse can touch Jacob;
    no magic has any power against Israel.
For now it will be said of Jacob,
    ‘What wonders God has done for Israel!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These people rise up like a lioness,
    like a majestic lion rousing itself.
They refuse to rest
    until they have feasted on prey,
    drinking the blood of the slaughtered!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “Fine, but if you won’t curse them, at least don’t bless them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Balaam replied to Balak, “Didn’t I tell you that I can do only what the Lord tells me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Balak said to Balaam, “Come, I will take you to one more place. Perhaps it will please God to let you curse them from there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, overlooking the wasteland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam again told Balak, “Build me seven altars, and prepare seven young bulls and seven rams for me to sacrifice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak did as Balaam ordered and offered a young bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By now Balaam realized that the Lord was determined to bless Israel, so he did not resort to divination as before. Instead, he turned and looked out toward the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where he saw the people of Israel camped, tribe by tribe. Then the Spirit of God came upon him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and this is the message he delivered:
“This is the message of Balaam son of Beor,
    the message of the man whose eyes see clearly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the message of one who hears the words of God,
    who sees a vision from the Almighty,
    who bows down with eyes wide open:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful are your tents, O Jacob;
    how lovely are your homes, O Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They spread before me like palm groves,
    like gardens by the riverside.
They are like tall trees planted by the Lord,
    like cedars beside the waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
God brought them out of Egypt;
    for them he is as strong as a wild ox.
He devours all the nations that oppose him,
    breaking their bones in pieces,
    shooting them with arrows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a lion, Israel crouches and lies down;
    like a lioness, who dares to arouse her?
Blessed is everyone who blesses you, O Israel,
    and cursed is everyone who curses you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Balak flew into a rage against Balaam. He angrily clapped his hands and shouted, “I called you to curse my enemies! Instead, you have blessed them three times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get out of here! Go back home! I promised to reward you richly, but the Lord has kept you from your reward.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam told Balak, “Don’t you remember what I told your messengers? I said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Even if Balak were to give me his palace filled with silver and gold, I would be powerless to do anything against the will of the Lord.’ I told you that I could say only what the Lord says!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I am returning to my own people. But first let me tell you what the Israelites will do to your people in the future.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the message Balaam delivered:
“This is the message of Balaam son of Beor,
    the message of the man whose eyes see clearly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the message of one who hears the words of God,
    who has knowledge from the Most High,
who sees a vision from the Almighty,
    who bows down with eyes wide open:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I see him, but not here and now.
    I perceive him, but far in the distant future.
A star will rise from Jacob;
    a scepter will emerge from Israel.
It will crush the heads of Moab’s people,
    cracking the skulls of the people of Sheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Edom will be taken over,
    and Seir, its enemy, will be conquered,
    while Israel marches on in triumph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A ruler will rise in Jacob
    who will destroy the survivors of Ir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Balaam looked over toward the people of Amalek and delivered this message:
“Amalek was the greatest of nations,
    but its destiny is destruction!”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
But the Kenites will be destroyed
    when Assyria takes you captive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Balaam concluded his messages by saying:
“Alas, who can survive
    unless God has willed it?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam left and returned home, and Balak also went on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the Israelites were camped at Acacia Grove, some of the men defiled themselves by having sexual relations with local Moabite women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These women invited them to attend sacrifices to their gods, so the Israelites feasted with them and worshiped the gods of Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way, Israel joined in the worship of Baal of Peor, causing the Lord’s anger to blaze against his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord issued the following command to Moses: “Seize all the ringleaders and execute them before the Lord in broad daylight, so his fierce anger will turn away from the people of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses ordered Israel’s judges, “Each of you must put to death the men under your authority who have joined in worshiping Baal of Peor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then one of the Israelite men brought a Midianite woman into his tent, right before the eyes of Moses and all the people, as everyone was weeping at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Phinehas son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest saw this, he jumped up and left the assembly. He took a spear
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and rushed after the man into his tent. Phinehas thrust the spear all the way through the man’s body and into the woman’s stomach. So the plague against the Israelites was stopped,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but not before 24,000 people had died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Phinehas son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest has turned my anger away from the Israelites by being as zealous among them as I was. So I stopped destroying all Israel as I had intended to do in my zealous anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now tell him that I am making my special covenant of peace with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this covenant, I give him and his descendants a permanent right to the priesthood, for in his zeal for me, his God, he purified the people of Israel, making them right with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelite man killed with the Midianite woman was named Zimri son of Salu, the leader of a family from the tribe of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman’s name was Cozbi; she was the daughter of Zur, the leader of a Midianite clan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Attack the Midianites and destroy them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they assaulted you with deceit and tricked you into worshiping Baal of Peor, and because of Cozbi, the daughter of a Midianite leader, who was killed at the time of the plague because of what happened at Peor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the plague had ended, the Lord said to Moses and to Eleazar son of Aaron the priest,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From the whole community of Israel, record the names of all the warriors by their families. List all the men twenty years old or older who are able to go to war.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, across from Jericho, Moses and Eleazar the priest issued these instructions to the leaders of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“List all the men of Israel twenty years old and older, just as the Lord commanded Moses.”
This is the record of all the descendants of Israel who came out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Reuben, Jacob’s oldest son:
The Hanochite clan, named after their ancestor Hanoch.
The Palluite clan, named after their ancestor Pallu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Hezronite clan, named after their ancestor Hezron.
The Carmite clan, named after their ancestor Carmi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Reuben. Their registered troops numbered 43,730.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pallu was the ancestor of Eliab,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Eliab was the father of Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. This Dathan and Abiram are the same community leaders who conspired with Korah against Moses and Aaron, rebelling against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the earth opened up its mouth and swallowed them with Korah, and fire devoured 250 of their followers. This served as a warning to the entire nation of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the sons of Korah did not die that day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Simeon:
The Jemuelite clan, named after their ancestor Jemuel.
The Jaminite clan, named after their ancestor Jamin.
The Jakinite clan, named after their ancestor Jakin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Zoharite clan, named after their ancestor Zohar.
The Shaulite clan, named after their ancestor Shaul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Simeon. Their registered troops numbered 22,200.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Gad:
The Zephonite clan, named after their ancestor Zephon.
The Haggite clan, named after their ancestor Haggi.
The Shunite clan, named after their ancestor Shuni.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Oznite clan, named after their ancestor Ozni.
The Erite clan, named after their ancestor Eri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Arodite clan, named after their ancestor Arodi.
The Arelite clan, named after their ancestor Areli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Gad. Their registered troops numbered 40,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah had two sons, Er and Onan, who had died in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from Judah’s surviving sons:
The Shelanite clan, named after their ancestor Shelah.
The Perezite clan, named after their ancestor Perez.
The Zerahite clan, named after their ancestor Zerah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the subclans descended from the Perezites:
The Hezronites, named after their ancestor Hezron.
The Hamulites, named after their ancestor Hamul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Judah. Their registered troops numbered 76,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Issachar:
The Tolaite clan, named after their ancestor Tola.
The Puite clan, named after their ancestor Puah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Jashubite clan, named after their ancestor Jashub.
The Shimronite clan, named after their ancestor Shimron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Issachar. Their registered troops numbered 64,300.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Zebulun:
The Seredite clan, named after their ancestor Sered.
The Elonite clan, named after their ancestor Elon.
The Jahleelite clan, named after their ancestor Jahleel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Zebulun. Their registered troops numbered 60,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two clans were descended from Joseph through Manasseh and Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from Manasseh:
The Makirite clan, named after their ancestor Makir.
The Gileadite clan, named after their ancestor Gilead, Makir’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the subclans descended from the Gileadites:
The Iezerites, named after their ancestor Iezer.
The Helekites, named after their ancestor Helek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Asrielites, named after their ancestor Asriel.
The Shechemites, named after their ancestor Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Shemidaites, named after their ancestor Shemida.
The Hepherites, named after their ancestor Hepher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (One of Hepher’s descendants, Zelophehad, had no sons, but his daughters’ names were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Manasseh. Their registered troops numbered 52,700.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Ephraim:
The Shuthelahite clan, named after their ancestor Shuthelah.
The Bekerite clan, named after their ancestor Beker.
The Tahanite clan, named after their ancestor Tahan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This was the subclan descended from the Shuthelahites:
The Eranites, named after their ancestor Eran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans of Ephraim. Their registered troops numbered 32,500.
These clans of Manasseh and Ephraim were all descendants of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Benjamin:
The Belaite clan, named after their ancestor Bela.
The Ashbelite clan, named after their ancestor Ashbel.
The Ahiramite clan, named after their ancestor Ahiram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Shuphamite clan, named after their ancestor Shupham.
The Huphamite clan, named after their ancestor Hupham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the subclans descended from the Belaites:
The Ardites, named after their ancestor Ard.
The Naamites, named after their ancestor Naaman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Benjamin. Their registered troops numbered 45,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Dan:
The Shuhamite clan, named after their ancestor Shuham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the Shuhamite clans of Dan. Their registered troops numbered 64,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Asher:
The Imnite clan, named after their ancestor Imnah.
The Ishvite clan, named after their ancestor Ishvi.
The Beriite clan, named after their ancestor Beriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the subclans descended from the Beriites:
The Heberites, named after their ancestor Heber.
The Malkielites, named after their ancestor Malkiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asher also had a daughter named Serah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Asher. Their registered troops numbered 53,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the clans descended from the sons of Naphtali:
The Jahzeelite clan, named after their ancestor Jahzeel.
The Gunite clan, named after their ancestor Guni.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Jezerite clan, named after their ancestor Jezer.
The Shillemite clan, named after their ancestor Shillem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the clans of Naphtali. Their registered troops numbered 45,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In summary, the registered troops of all Israel numbered 601,730.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Divide the land among the tribes, and distribute the grants of land in proportion to the tribes’ populations, as indicated by the number of names on the list.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give the larger tribes more land and the smaller tribes less land, each group receiving a grant in proportion to the size of its population.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must assign the land by lot, and give land to each ancestral tribe according to the number of names on the list.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each grant of land must be assigned by lot among the larger and smaller tribal groups.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the record of the Levites who were counted according to their clans:
The Gershonite clan, named after their ancestor Gershon.
The Kohathite clan, named after their ancestor Kohath.
The Merarite clan, named after their ancestor Merari.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Libnites, the Hebronites, the Mahlites, the Mushites, and the Korahites were all subclans of the Levites.
Now Kohath was the ancestor of Amram,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Amram’s wife was named Jochebed. She also was a descendant of Levi, born among the Levites in the land of Egypt. Amram and Jochebed became the parents of Aaron, Moses, and their sister, Miriam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Aaron were born Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nadab and Abihu died when they burned before the Lord the wrong kind of fire, different than he had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men from the Levite clans who were one month old or older numbered 23,000. But the Levites were not included in the registration of the rest of the people of Israel because they were not given an allotment of land when it was divided among the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So these are the results of the registration of the people of Israel as conducted by Moses and Eleazar the priest on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River, across from Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Not one person on this list had been among those listed in the previous registration taken by Moses and Aaron in the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord had said of them, “They will all die in the wilderness.” Not one of them survived except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day a petition was presented by the daughters of Zelophehad—Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah. Their father, Zelophehad, was a descendant of Hepher son of Gilead, son of Makir, son of Manasseh, son of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These women stood before Moses, Eleazar the priest, the tribal leaders, and the entire community at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Our father died in the wilderness,” they said. “He was not among Korah’s followers, who rebelled against the Lord; he died because of his own sin. But he had no sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should the name of our father disappear from his clan just because he had no sons? Give us property along with the rest of our relatives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses brought their case before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord replied to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The claim of the daughters of Zelophehad is legitimate. You must give them a grant of land along with their father’s relatives. Assign them the property that would have been given to their father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And give the following instructions to the people of Israel: If a man dies and has no son, then give his inheritance to his daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if he has no daughter either, transfer his inheritance to his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he has no brothers, give his inheritance to his father’s brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if his father has no brothers, give his inheritance to the nearest relative in his clan. This is a legal requirement for the people of Israel, just as the Lord commanded Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day the Lord said to Moses, “Climb one of the mountains east of the river, and look out over the land I have given the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After you have seen it, you will die like your brother, Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for you both rebelled against my instructions in the wilderness of Zin. When the people of Israel rebelled, you failed to demonstrate my holiness to them at the waters.” (These are the waters of Meribah at Kadesh in the wilderness of Zin.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “O Lord, you are the God who gives breath to all creatures. Please appoint a new man as leader for the community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give them someone who will guide them wherever they go and will lead them into battle, so the community of the Lord will not be like sheep without a shepherd.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord replied, “Take Joshua son of Nun, who has the Spirit in him, and lay your hands on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
